awd_titl_txt: Accelerated Reactions in Droplets and Thin Films: Surface Effects and Analytical Implications
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Graham Cooks and his group at Purdue University are working to explain and exploit a startling but simple fact: the speed of many chemical reactions increases dramatically as the volume of the reacting mixture decreases.  Because of this, reactions in microdroplets can easily be thousands of times faster than the same reactions in jars, barrels or industrial vats.  This may offer an alternative to the use of expensive chemical catalysts to save time and energy.  Research in the Cooks group is focused on understanding the role of the droplet interface in accelerating reactions, particularly those that are useful in various analytical measurements.  Among other potential applications are studies of the shelf life of pharmaceuticals, and detailed examination of fast biochemical reactions that occur within living cells. The project provides training in advanced instrumentation and precision chemical measurements, and prepares graduate students to contribute to the US workforce in a field with strong industrial and national security ties.  A range of methods will be deployed to transfer the results of the research and strengthen the training aspect of the program, including strong industrial interactions, focused short training courses, inclusion of undergraduates in research, and collaborative research efforts involving regional institutions with strength in analytical chemistry.

The research objectives of this proposal are to discover and characterize ways to exploit accelerated reactions (including derivatization) for chemical analysis in droplets and other confined volumes, and to elucidate the mechanisms that increase reaction rate constants. The search for mechanistic knowledge focusses on kinetic studies of surface vs. bulk reactions as a function of droplet size and reagent concentration.  Mass spectrometry can benefit from as well as probe these reactions.  It is the main measurement tool, along with interfacial vibrational spectrometry.  Other target applications come from both academic and industrial settings. Examples include chemical reactions involving non-covalent clusters of amino acids and peptide bond formation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

PROJECT OUTCOMES

            The research objective of this grant was to apply accelerated reactions in microdroplets and other confined volumes to chemical analysis, chemical derivatization, and small-scale synthesis, and to elucidate the mechanisms that result in the dramatic increases seen in the reaction rate constants.          

            These studies advanced our understanding of microdroplet chemistry. First, we addressed the origin of reaction acceleration in microdroplets and found that the partially solvated state of the molecules at the solution/air interface of microdroplets is a primary cause. Other studies revealed that the existence of a high electric field and the superacid gas/solution interface favors acceleration. Our investigations also suggested that the molecularity of the reaction controls acceleration, with bimolecular reactions being accelerated, whereas the unimolecular reactions were not. Experimentally, we identified several key reactive intermediates, notably the water radical cation/anion pair in microdroplets containing at least a trace amount of water. These active radical species were shown to be responsible for the simultaneous reduction and oxidation of compounds in microdroplets. The coexistence of these oxidizing and reducing species is suggested to be due to the presence of a double-layer structure and high electric field at the microdroplet surface. A variety of molecules having X=Y moieties, such as ketone, ester, sulfone, sulfonamide, and carbamate, were shown to be spontaneously oxidized by the water radical cation as seen by direct measurement of the adduct ion.

            This accelerated reaction format in microdroplets was also applied to click chemistry. More specifically, the SuFEx reaction (a click reaction) was shown to be accelerated in microdroplets even in the absence of a catalyst, and the scope of this reaction was explored in a high-throughput format. The superacidic microdroplet surface favored the SuFEx reaction. In another study, we utilized the azo-click and alkenylation reactions to chemically modify Ezetimibe, a well-known hypertension drug, using high-throughput desorption electrospray ionization (DESI) mass spectrometry. The effect of the choice of reactant, stoichiometry, catalyst, and solvent on late-stage functionalization reaction was studied. Overall, microdroplet chemistry emerged as an effective method to accomplish derivatization reactions. In another area of study: glass was shown to act as a green heterogeneous catalyst (base), increasing the rates of reactions by more than two orders of magnitude over bulk solution.

            We designed a closed-cycle solvent-recycling apparatus to perform accelerated microdroplet/thin film reactions to achieve gram-scale synthesis of reaction products. Claisen-Schmidt, Schiff base, Katritzky, and Suzuki coupling reactions were used as test reactions to show the scale up.  In another study, accelerated synthesis of benzimidazole was achieved by reacting to 1,2-aromatic diamines and alkyl or aryl carboxylic acids reacting in electrostatically charged microdroplets. The synthetic method was scaled-up to establish the substituent dependence and to isolate products for NMR characterization. Apart from organic synthesis, different nanomaterials were also shown to be synthesized by the spray deposition of metal salt-containing microdroplets. These as-synthesized nanomaterials can be utilized as catalysts. We showed that the gentle deposition of the Cu-containing droplets onto the liquid surface formed a thin film of catalyst which promoted the heterogeneous azide-alkyne cycloaddition reaction while showing diffusion-controlled kinetics.

            We observed a potentially significant CO2 removal reaction with non-volatile primary amine to be accelerated in microdroplets (especially those containing some proportion of water). This reaction yielded carbamic acids, highlighting the key role of trace amounts of water to provide superacid/base at the gas/liquid interface. We are extending this study to efficiently capture CO2 on a practical scale by using reactive microdroplets. In another study, unique dipeptide isomers, generated from glycine or L-alanine at the air-water interface of aqueous microdroplets, were discovered and characterized as oxazolidinones. The interface of microdroplets serves as a drying surface which favors dehydration and leading to the stabilization of the dipeptide isomers. We suggest that the dry interface of aqueous microdroplets may be responsible for the condensation reaction to form peptides (as well as nucleosides, oligonucleotides, and glycopeptides) and so may have direct implications for the origin of life. We also showed that the electrosprayed microdroplets can be utilized for ambient analysis of small molecules using a miniature mass spectrometer. We expanded the analytical capabilities of MS/MS by introducing a two-dimensional tandem mass (2D MS/MS) scan, in which all precursor ions and their subsequent product ions are identified and correlated in a single rapid scan. The 2D MS/MS method was successfully used to analyze different multicomponent mixtures including drugs of abuse, peptides, and fentanyl analogs, electrosprayed in the form of microdroplets.
